page.title: 13Some Flowers of Dartmoor
page.content: It is a fallacy to suggest Dartmoor is a barren sheep clipped place. On the contrary there are several flowers that enliven the rocky landscape. Nestling close to the ground is the yellow of the Tormentil. This flower was used as a medicine by the moormen, being especially good for stomach upsets. The tiny clumps of white flowers of the Heath Bedstraw again were useful to the tinners and others that had to live on the moor. These were used to stuff the matresses, and when the sleeper turned over a pleasant smell resulted. Probably just as well, since the tinners huts must have been rather smelly. Finally, in the spring nestling beneath the rocks, one can see the blue of the violet. It hides away, but can be found if searched for.
